Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CHS: Enhancing Patient-Clinician Communication through Self-Monitoring Data Sharing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research aims to understand the enablers and barriers in sharing self-monitoring data collected from the ever-evolving wearable sensing and mobile health technology. Self-monitoring data can provide good measures of everyday health behavior that are often not well captured by traditional methods such as regular visits to clinicians. However, self-monitoring data is largely underutilized by patients and clinicians due to many obstacles, including difficulty in data sharing. Current information technology is inadequate for patients to easily share their self-monitoring data with clinicians. Based on the understanding of current challenges and design opportunities, novel information technology will be designed for assisting patients and clinicians to effectively collaborate and communicate. The long-term goal is to help patients be active observers and participants in their own care, and assist clinicians leverage patients' self-monitoring data in their medical decision-making.

Using human-centered design approaches, observations and interviews will be conducted with patients and clinicians to understand how they currently share self-monitoring data. The focus will be on workarounds and breakdowns. Based on the findings, participatory design and iterative design approaches will identify design opportunities that can meet patients' and clinicians' data sharing needs. These efforts will culminate in the design of lightweight technology probes that enhance our understanding of how self-monitoring data sharing should be incorporated into health care and clinical workflow. Successful completion of this research will provide: (1) a deeper understanding of patients' and clinicians' barriers toward personal health data sharing and a set of functional design and information requirements to address the barriers, (2) light-weight technology probes that embody these requirements based on participatory and iterative design approaches, and (3) a needs assessment with probes for learning receptiveness toward self-monitoring data sharing. This research will advance the field of human-computer interaction and health informatics by deepening our understanding of how self-monitoring data collected from wearable sensing and mobile health technology can be incorporated into clinical care.

POR.DRECONTENT:
People are collecting a wide range of personal health data due to the prevalence of mobile and sensing technologies. The potential usefulness of these data is enormous as they can provide good measures of people’s behavior and lifestyle. However, how to fully leverage patient-generated data (PGD) and to integrate them into the clinical practice is less clear. The overarching goal of this research is to examine what challenges patients and clinicians face when they share patient-generated data, with an aim to designing technologies that afford seamless collaboration between patients and clinicians around patient-generated data.

To this end, we conducted interviews with clinicians and patients, as well as a survey study with patients to understand current barriers in sharing patient-generated data. We also conducted observations in a sleep clinic to understand the workflow of clinicians and data sharing practice in the context of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I) treatment. Lastly, we organized a design workshop to discuss and build design scenarios to identify target users and opportunities for leveraging patient-clinician data sharing and collaborative decision making.

From these research activities, we identified technical, social, and organizational challenges in sharing and using patient-generated data in clinical practices.  Our results showed that depending on who initiate the tracking—whether clinicians or patients—the value of the patient-generated data was perceived differently: Patient-initiated tracking data were not often shared or valued, whereas clinician-initiated tracking data were perceived to be useful and were often shared. When shared, the most common method was verbal sharing during the clinic visit. Most clinician participants noted time constraint as an important barrier that impedes data sharing. Most patient participants worried that their data might not be relevant to their health issue, and thus, disturb clinicians. We also learned that most self-trackers (including patients) fail to fully make sense of their self-tracked data.

We see opportunities in making the patient-generated data more useful and relevant by involving clinicians early on to provide guidance to patients on what data to collect and how to collect them. Moreover, data visualizations, analytics, and summarization techniques will play an important role in making patient-generated data valuable for clinicians and patients, helping them quickly gain critical insights and reflect on the data. As a starting point, we designed Visualized Self, with which we aimed to help self-trackers explore their personal data and gain insights. We also designed ChartAccent, which is a chart annotation tool for emphasizing and communicating key insights in the charts.

The technical contributions of our work advance the fields of human-computer interaction, information visualization, and health informatics, by deepening our understanding of how self-monitoring data can be incorporated into clinical care. Results from our work were published in human-computer interaction venues (CHI 2017, PervasiveHealth 2017), health informatics venue (AMIA 2016), and information visualization venue (PacificVis 2017). We also published our vision of harnessing patient-generated data in IEEE Pervasive Computing (2018). We also made the data annotation tool, ChartAccent available on the web: https://chartaccent.github.io. As part of the educational program for this research, the Principal Investigator designed and offered a graduate-level course titled, “Design Thinking for Health Technologies,” as well as advised several undergraduate and graduate students. This work also addresses a major public health goal of empowering individuals and provides design recommendations for patient-centered care to improve patient outcomes.
